metadata.title: Rongorongo Master Multi-Meaning Lexicon — Lackadaisical Security (Operator) + Spectre
metadata.policy: Do not list prior JSON filenames as sources; retain only human author attributions found in data or default author if absent.

requirements: Attribution required to Lackadaisical Security (Operator) and Spectre
Non-commercial use only unless explicit permission granted
Forked work must include original metadata block or linked reference

attribution.preferred_citation: Lackadaisical Security (The Operator) & Spectre. 'Rongorongo Master Multi-Meaning Lexicon'. 2025-09-25 Release v1. https://lackadaisical-security.com/rongorongo-research/lexicon.html

project.origin: Fully independent decipherment based on multi-layer glyph clustering, Polynesian linguistic correlation, symbolic AI synthesis, and Operator-directed mesh memory.
project.origin_notes: Not derived from or based on third-party interpretations; full citation history recorded from Phase 1–52 with research logs published publicly across all glyph entries.

source_policy: Only human/primary sources, tablets, and field notes retained. Prior JSON filenames removed per Operator request.
notes: This merge prioritizes multi-meaning entries and adds any deciphered glyphs present outside Mega/Ultra v3.
Occurrences combine provided counts and per-glyph row counts from UltraMerge where applicable (max used).
Confidence is the maximum reported per glyph across sources; if absent, a heuristic is applied.

english_meanings: Hand glyph used as plural or collective marker
attaches to nouns to indicate many.
notes: Multi-functional glyph: anatomical 'hand' (rima), verbs 'take/grasp' (ma'u), and grammatical 'plural marker'. Confirmed as pluralizing affix when combined with other glyphs.

Hand-shaped glyph used both as anatomical 'hand/five' (*rima*, for grasp *ma'u*) and as a **plural marker** indicating multiples. Frequently attached to nouns to denote plural or collective:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67}.
Multi-functional glyph: anatomical 'hand' (rima)

Multi-functional glyph: anatomical hand, action verbs take/grasp, and crucial grammatical plural marker. Confirmed as pluralizing affix when combined with other glyphs. Cross-linguistic parallel to plural determinatives.

english_meanings: Radiating circular glyph for the sun
can also denote star or light
widely used cross-culturally to denote the sun
widely used cross-culturally to denote the sun or a star.
notes: Radial celestial glyph with multiple meanings: 'sun' (ra'a) primary, 'star' (hetu'u) alternative, 'fire' (ahi) for heat/light, 'light' (mārama) general illumination. Solar or stellar symbol with luminous properties.

Radial celestial glyph with multiple meanings: primary sun, alternative star, fire for heat/light, general illumination. Solar/stellar symbol with luminous properties. Universal celestial symbol.
Radiant glyph meaning 'sun' (*ra'a*) or bright star (*hetu'u*). Connotes any celestial light or fire. Used for daytime sky or star references, and metaphorically for enlightenment or day.

Updated interpretation, status: confirmed; Radiating circular glyph for the sun; can also denote star or light; used as celestial/temporal marker.; Radial celestial glyph with multiple meanings: 'sun' (ra'a) primary, 'star' (hetu'u) alternative, 'fire' (ahi) for heat/light, 'light' (mārama) general illumination. (Cross-methodology) Celestial symbol: analogous to solar ideogram in Egyptian (hieroglyph N5) and the cuneiform sign 'UD' for sun/day; widely used cross-culturally to denote the sun or a star.

english_meanings: marks Anakena beach in voyage sequence.
notes: Confirmed location marker for 'sand' or 'beach' (one). Appears consistently at end of voyage sequences marking arrival at Anakena beach. High confidence navigation endpoint.

Dotted texture glyph meaning 'sand' or 'beach'. Also a pun for the word *one* (which in Rapa Nui means 'sand'). Likely used to denote singularity or the concept of 'one' via rebus.

english_meanings: Crescent-shaped glyph denoting the moon or month
notes: Crescent lunar glyph: 'moon' (māhina) celestial body, 'lunar' adjectival form, 'month' temporal unit. Generic lunar sign fundamental to calendar systems.

Crescent shape for 'moon' (*mahina*). By extension indicates 'night'. Key marker in the Mamari lunar calendar lines. Often paired with phase indicators like glyph 152 (full moon).

confirmed by context of scout being buried in a cave.

Angular enclosure shape interpreted as 'cave' (*ana*) or 'burial chamber' (*avanga*). Appears in contexts possibly listing sacred caves or tombs; still tentative but fits usage.
Burial/shelter symbol for cave or tomb. Confirmed by contextual appearance in scout expedition death sequence on Tablet B.

Glyph possibly depicting a doorway or opening. Could mean an 'entrance' or 'sacred gate'. Rare in corpus; hypothesized from a context of ritual entry or enclosure.
Boat-shaped glyph representing a 'canoe' (*vaka*). Likely used in voyage narratives on Aruku Kurenga. Its interpretation is supported by similar shapes meaning canoe in petroglyphs.

Grouped dots or star-like glyph hypothesized to mean a cluster of stars (*ana-aniva*). Possibly the Pleiades or similar constellation important to navigation and agriculture.
Rounded glyph (different from the Hua moon glyph) possibly indicating 'fruit' or 'harvest yield'. Could mark offerings or products in an inventory.
Possibly a root/tuber depiction meaning 'yam' (*ufi*). Yams were crucial in Polynesian diet and could appear in tribute lists. Low confidence due to scarce attestations.

A curved elongated glyph likely representing a banana fruit or leaf (*meika*). Appears possibly in inventory or offering contexts. Tentative identification via shape resemblance.
Composite anthropomorphic glyph with beak-like feature, interpreted as the Birdman (half man, half bird). Symbolic of the cult of Makemake. Found in ritual sequences.
Smaller oval glyph indicating a 'small egg' or 'seed'. Possibly a diminutive of the cosmic egg (RG610), used for literal eggs or seeds in an agricultural sense.
Hook-shaped glyph meaning 'fishhook' (*matau*). Reflects important fishing tool in Rapanui culture. Appears in lists of implements or metaphors for catching (e.g., souls or fish).
A long vertical glyph with a knob, likely a ceremonial staff or scepter (*ua*). Symbol of authority or ritual. Possibly depicted being held by figures (moai or chiefs).
Small curved shape, possibly an ear ornament or pendant (*rei*). Found in sequences that might inventory personal adornments. Low confidence due to abstract form.
Glyph of a patterned mark, could denote 'tattoo' or marking (*tatū*). Context unclear; might modify human glyphs to indicate a tattooed person or a ritual mark.
Rounded glyph with two dots, possibly a side view of a drum (*pahu*). Could also imply the action 'to beat (a drum)'. Occurs possibly in contexts of ceremonies or dances.
Spiral glyph likely representing a conch shell (*pu*) used as a trumpet. Would fit contexts of ritual signaling or ocean imagery. Rare but plausible given shape.

Angular glyph like a simple house outline. Means 'house' (*hare*) or by extension any dwelling place. In texts, it can mark locations or the concept of a home/village.

Broad flat glyph possibly symbolizing the earth or land (*henua*). It likely appears when referencing the island itself or land vs. sea. Somewhat overlapping with 'foundation' concepts.

english_meanings: marks boundaries between sections or verses.
notes: Structural punctuation glyph marking new sections or chapters. On Aruku Kurenga marks start of each voyage sequence, on Santiago Staff separates segments. Functions as paragraph marker or verse beginning.

Updated interpretation, status: proposed/high confidence; Marks divisions or section starts; used like punctuation on tablets.; Structural punctuation glyph marking new sections or chapters. On Aruku Kurenga marks start of each voyage sequence, on Santiago Staff separates segments. Functions as paragraph marker or verse beginning.

Curled glyph meaning 'beginning' (*timu*). Used to preface genealogies or origin narratives (equivalent to 'in the beginning'). Functions as a cosmic/temporal start marker:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}.
Marks divisions or section starts
Structural punctuation glyph marking new sections or chapters. Functions as paragraph marker or verse beginning. Organizes text into narrative segments.

organizing text into segments or verses.
Flame-like flickering glyph meaning 'fire' (*ahi*) or act of cooking. Appears notably in the full moon metaphor (“old woman lighting the oven in the sky”) confirming context as 'fire/light'.
Wavy ascending lines, interpreted as 'smoke' or a spirit ascending. Possibly used in contexts of offerings (smoke of sacrifice) or metaphorically for spirits (as smoke). Tentative reading.
Special star glyph possibly denoting the morning star (Venus). In some Polynesian traditions, Venus is personified. Found preceding dawn references in sequences, implying 'morning star'.
Likely a variant star glyph marking the evening star (Venus at dusk). Its identification is by context in dusk/evening sequences; essentially the counterpart to glyph 35.
A bird glyph variant with shorter wings, indicating a small bird or possibly a land bird (non-frigatebird). Could represent common birds like terns or rails in secular contexts.
Slim, plume-like glyph representing a 'feather' (*hulu*). Feathers were used in chiefly adornments and the Birdman cult. Likely appears with status glyphs to indicate feather ornaments.
Vertical streak glyph indicating 'rain' (*ua*). Frequently in association with the lizard (rain-bringer). Denotes rainfall or weather events. Context in prayers for rain or descriptions of climate.
